section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for the whole Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors monitoring SSL certificates on the target URL

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for link in each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for resources in each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for the total health of the Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: The target URL is unavailable

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen for a few reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The target URL is down for maintenance or unavailable
There is a firewall between the watcher node and the URL
System proxy settings are not set for the watcher node

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Try the following troubleshooting steps to attempt to fix the problem

maml:listItem.maml:para: Ping the target URL to ensure it's on the network
Configure the system proxy settings on each of the watcher nodes

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: An error was encountered while processing an URL.

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen for a few reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The page is unreachable. If behind a proxy, check if the proxy settings are correct.
Unexpected API call failures. Multiple reasons could cause this, for instance a memory allocation error.
The site or URL is not accessible or is down.

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Try to access the same URL from an internet browser like Internet Explorer.

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: Could not resolve the user supplied URL through the watcher nodes Domain Name Service.

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen for a few reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The DNS client side cache has a stale entry
The DNS infrastructure not available
The watcher node DNS settings are out of date or incorrect
DNS has a stale entry for the supplied target name and is returning the wrong IP address

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Try the following troubleshooting steps to attempt to fix the problem

maml:listItem.maml:para: On a Windows Computer, at the command line type:
ipconfig /flushdns
Then type:
ipconfig /registerdns
Check with your network or domain administrator if there is any problems with the DNS infrastructure that the watcher node is configured to use.
Check the URL can be pinged. Note that in some cases, the network path from the watcher node to the URL may not allow ICMP, so ping may fail.
Do this by pinging by the URL name you supplied in the wizard. Type ping -a [URL]. For example, if the IP Address is www.microsoft.com:

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: Status code does not match the supplied criteria

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen for a few reasons:

maml:listItem.maml:para: The target URL is offline
The watcher node doesn't have the appropriate permissions
There may be a firewall between the watcher node and the target device

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Try the following troubleshooting steps to attempt to fix the problem

maml:listItem.maml:para: Open IE to confirm that the target URL is online
Ensure that the Run As account used by the watcher node has the appropriate permissions to the target data source
Check if the Windows Firewall is enabled on either the target machine or the watcher node. If it is, create an exclusion for the application you are monitoring.

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: SSL Certificate has Expired

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: The servers servicing this URL has an expired SSL Certificate

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Contact the administrator of the URL to update their SSL certificate

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: SSL Certificate CA Root not trusted

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen when the target URL is not using an SSL certificate that is signed by a public internet root CA.

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Contact the administrator of the URL to use a publicly signed SSL certificate or add the Certificate to the watcher nodes trusted root CA store if you are in fact sure you should be trusting this source. For example if you have an internal Root CA that supplies SSL certificates.

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: The CN for this Certificate is invalid

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen when the certificate is invalid

maml:listItem.maml:para: The watcher node doesn't have the appropriate permissions

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Contact the administrator of the URL to ensure they have a properly configured SSL certificate.

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: One of the links on this page does not match the status code criteria

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen when one or more links on the page results in a status code that doesn't match the criteria provided by the wizard by default.

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Edit the web application monitoring from the Authoring space and check the criteria for links

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: One of the resources on this page does not match the status code criteria

section.maml:title: Causes
section.maml:para: This can happen when one or more resources (e.g. images, cascading style sheets, scripts, etc...) on the page results in a status code that doesn't match the criteria provided by the wizard by default.

section.maml:title: Resolutions
section.maml:para: Edit the web application monitoring from the Authoring space and check the criteria for links

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for the whole Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors monitoring SSL certificates on the target URL

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for link in each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for resources in each request in this Web Application

section.maml:title: Summary
section.maml:para: This rolls up health from all the individual monitors for the total health of the Web Application

Do this by pinging by the URL name you supplied in the wizard. Type ping -a [URL]. For example, if the IP Address is www.microsoft.com:
